title: Keith Vaz rushed to hospital hours after damning report on cocaine scandal
text:
Keith Vaz has been admitted to hospital, a statement on his website said (Picture: MJ-Pictures/Getty)

Keith Vaz was admitted to hospital hours after a damning report recommended he be suspended for six months for offering to buy cocaine for two male escorts.

A statement on the Labour MP’s website last night said he has been treated for a serious mental health condition for the last three years as a result of the 2016 scandal.

It added that he was admitted to hospital and will not be making any further comments.

Yesterday, the Commons Standards Committee said Mr Vaz breached its code of conduct ‘by expressing willingness to purchase cocaine for another person’.

It added that he had shown ‘disrespect for the House’s standards system’ and caused ‘significant damage’ to the reputation and integrity of the Commons as a whole because he had failed to co-operate fully with the Commons inquiry process.

Mr Vaz’s statement said he ‘vigorously rejects’ the allegation that he has failed to cooperate with the inquiry and said that – as commissioner Kathryn Stone had found – he had not committed any criminal acts.

Keith Vaz spotted in Heathrow airport two days before the recommendation he be suspended from the House of Commons for six months (Picture: MJ-Pictures)

The married MP stepped down as chairman of the Home Affairs Committee in 2016 after being accused of paying for the services of two male escorts.

Mr Vaz issued a public apology at the time for the ‘hurt and distress’ caused to his wife and children.

The scandal was exposed by the Sunday Mirror who claimed the MP hid his real identity from the men he was attempting to buy drugs for, instead telling them he was a washing machine salesman called Jim.

In her damning report following the inquiry – which launched in 2016 – the commissioner found that it was ‘more likely than not that Mr Vaz has engaged in paid sexual activity’.

She also said that an audio recording one of the men made in Mr Vaz’s flat ‘contains evidence of Mr Vaz’s apparent willingness to purchase controlled drugs for others to use’.

The MP’s statement said: ‘The events of 27 August 2016 were purely personal and private, and occurred in circumstances where neither Mr Vaz’s public nor his Parliamentary role were engaged.

‘Mr Vaz has never bought, possessed, dealt with or used illegal drugs.

‘He has a cardiovascular condition which would mean that were he to consume any non-prescribed drugs he would in all likelihood die.’

If approved by the Commons, Mr Vaz’s six-month suspension will trigger the terms of recall legislation, allowing constituents to sign a petition on whether Mr Vaz should be forced to seek re-election to his Leicester East seat.
